did.head: Collection Summary

origination.label: Creator

did.abstract: The Soviet Union Innokentievtsy Subject Files contain documents detailing the history of the group, public perception, and recruitment of young adults.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Soviet Union Innokentievtsy Subject Files contain bibliographies, articles, and newspaper clippings from 1962-1979 with an emphasis on 1970-1971 and 1979. The documents primarily focus on public perception and critique of the group, but also contain information about the founding and recruitment of young adults. Some key subjects within the documents include youth, wandering, not working, persecution, recruitment, underground chambers, Orthodox, bride of God, and live burial.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received the Soviet Union Innokentievtsy in one folder. Some individual documents were labeled and filed accordingly. All materials are organized by date.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to the Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Soviet Union Innokentievtsy Subject Files, Box #, Folder #, Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society, Baylor University.

processinfo.p: Described by Larisa Seago. Released on 2021-12-10.

bioghist.p: Bibliography, articles, and newspaper clippings detailing public perception, founding, and recruitment of Innokentievtsy
